captions.text: *upbeat synth music*
if you're going through a breakup your heartbreak may feel like
physical pain and you're probably right
the sensation of heartbreak might be a result of your body's
instinct to simultaneously speed up and slow down your heartbeat. One study
examined the brains of people who were recently broken up with
the subjects were shown pictures of their exes
the fMRI revealed that the sadness they felt while looking at the photos
induced activity in the part of the brain that also registers
physical pain. This is because emotional
and physical pain share neural pathways in the brain. Going through a breakup might
also create sleeplessness, weight gain, and
overall decreased critical thinking.
This is due to the steady release of the stress hormone, cortisol.
If it feels difficult to let go of your ex
it might be because they were like a drug to your brain. You became accustomed to
your ex being in your life.
Now that they're gone, your neural circuits must readjust to the new
circumstances.
Going through a breakup sucks, but it won't last forever.
With time your body's chemistry will revert back to normal
and you'll be stronger than you ever thought you could be.
*upbeat synth music*

title: What Happens To Your Body During A Breakup?

comments.text:
I remember this dude I was with for nearly 3 years called me right whenever 
I got off work, I was walking to the subway station and he's talking all 
normal, told me how cute I am, how was my day and such then literally all 
in about a 10 minute phone call he simply said he's breaking up with me.. I 
couldn't believe my ears, I thought it was the wind or something so I 
chuckled a little bit then asked him what he said and he repeated it. I ran 
into this 7-11 right by the station, went to the restroom and tried to 
catch my breath and breathe normally. I cried in that bathroom for about 30 
minutes before I went out again, I missed my train and I had to wait for a 
long time, people looked at me funny because I was trembling and couldn't 
stop crying. It was very cold and I literally felt like someone jumped me. 
I finally got home, I walked most of the way. I locked myself in the closet 
for 2 days and could only think of suicide. A day later I had to come out 
and be "normal"on Christmas day with my family. I just told YouTube my 
break up story... I don't know why. But hey it DOES get better. I was 
single for a while and really had time to be okay with myself. The past 
year and a half I've been with the most sweet, and amazing man I could ever 
dream of. If I hadn't been dumped over the phone at a 7-11 then I wouldn't 
be able to have found my true soul mate, or even better understand and 
accept myself during the time that I was single. Good luck guys, I'm sorry 
if any of you have recently been through a break up. :/ (Hugs)﻿

I'm desperate. The thing that scares me the most is that I always knew she

comments.author: condenador

comments.text:
Even though it may seem excruciating, you have to wait it out. Take it one 
step at a time. Give yourself a rest, sleep, eat, cry. Let everything out. 
Then, push yourself to get over her. Accept that she isn't the one, and is 
not worth your time anymore. Love yourself. Meet other people. Before you 
start this process, though, eliminate every communication from her. Delete 
her number, unfollow her on all social media sites, avoid her in person. 
Because if you don't, then she'll always be there, hovering around you. 
Before you realize it, she'll be off your mind and you can move to your 
next potential lover. :)

comments.author: Gabby

comments.text:
There's no pain like heartbreak. I know that sounds dramatic, but breaking 
your arm or a severe injury sucks, sure, but you know in your head the pain 
won't last. The tricky thing about heartbreak is that it often convinces 
you the pain will never end, that you'll never be 100% again, but that 
isn't true. I guess I'm leaving this comment as an encouragement to those 
going through a breakup. Whether you were broken up with or you did the 
breaking, the pain is real for both parties, assuming intentions were 
genuine..give it time. Don't act irrationally. Have some self-respect and 
pull yourself up to your feet. Set new goals, focus. Improve yourself. Try 
to look at the big picture. A good friend or two can help tremendously. 
You'll be okay again. Not just okay. You'll be a new and improved 100%. 
Look forward to that day :)﻿
